newsitem.title: UK: UK's Labour calls for passports for HK Asians.
newsitem.headline: UK's Labour calls for passports for HK Asians.

text.p: Britain's opposition Labour party on Thursday called on the government to drop its opposition to a bill giving full British citizenship to 8,000 mainly Asian residents of Hong Kong after it is handed over to China in July.

The 8,000, most of them of South Asian descent, say they will effectively be left stateless after the July 1 handover as Chinese citizenship is based on ethnic criteria and Britain is denying them full citizenship.
Instead, they are being offered the status of British overseas citizens or nationals, which allows them to travel on British-issued passports but gives no right to live in Britain.

A bill to change this, drawn up by a peer, Lord Willoughby de Broke, is going through the British parliament. But Prime Minister John Major's government opposes it and without official backing it stands no chance of becoming law.
Labour's home affairs spokesman Jack Straw made his plea for a change of heart in a letter sent to Home Secretary Michael Howard on Thursday and released to the media.
Straw said: "Common sense and common humanity demand that we give these people full British citizenship.
"The limbo in which they will find themselves in July arises directly from the agreements which Britain made with China."
Home Office officials were unavailable for comment.

Britain cedes sovereignty of its last Asian outpost at midnight on June 30, 1997. Under a joint declaration signed in 1984, China is required to maintain Hong Kong's capitalist freedoms and way of life intact for 50 years.
But the two sides are currently at odds over democratic reforms introduced in the final years of British rule.
China has unveiled plans to dilute Hong Kong's laws guaranteeing civil liberties, including a Bill of Rights, sparking outrage in Hong Kong and objections from London.
